Dear All,

Well I've settled on the following:
1) Keep the UI test (it drives the UI implementation and tests that code
from a constrained input perspective).
2) Drill down and write specific tests for the underlying logic
implementation (if applicable).  In this case it was because the underlying
listener didn't have any test code for it.
3) Implement (2) and check the fix (1).

I've chosen this because my current fault *didn't* have any test code for
(2) and when added - I only got a green bar!?  So closer inspection of (1) I
noted that I was actually wrapping a number of DocumentListeners to get the
effect I desired - unfortunately I was add them in the wrong order.  So
whilst (1) on its own would have worked, I like (2) as well because the
listener can be used in a number of different ways and (1) only tests a
specific usage.

Thank you

Jonathan


On 07 June 2004 15:00, I wrote: 
> A while ago I started looking at using one of the frameworks available for
> testing UI code 
<snip/>

> Now I come to the validation process and I have received a number of 
> bugs to fix (no big deal) but my question is how much should I drive 
> my bug fixing? Normally (prior to abbot) I'd dig about my code to locate 
> the appropriate code, create a test case (or cases) to highlight the bug 
> and drive the fix appropriately.  Now I have a UI fault that is easy to 
> reproduce - and I've created a test case using abbot to highlight the
fault, 
> and can now dig through the code and fix it... but... this fault (as with 
> a couple of other UI faults) resolves down to a failing implementation of 
> some DocumentListener logic.  
>
> So should I (would you) keep TDD the fix via the high level UI test case, 
> or drill down and write "lower" level test cases for the DocumentListener
> implementation.
